text: [music playing]

ADAM GOLDSTEIN: Flying
through Dubai on Monday.

Marissa's not looking
forward to the travel ban,

because the kids won't be
able to play with their iPads
on the flight.

We hope that they
switch the ban around

so our kids can
be occupied and we
can get some sleep as parents.
[music playing]

EMILY STALKFLEET: My husband
and I will be traveling together

and are generally incredibly
frustrated by the inconvenience

and abruptness of the
upcoming electronics ban.

We both have jobs allow
us to work remotely

and had been planning
to work from the plane

and can no longer do
so, which means we have
to take an extra day of PTO.
[music playing]

ADAM ABDOUL: So basically what
that regulation is telling

me is that I won't be able to
use my computer for a good 36

hours, which I can use
this whole time to do

something else-- to do
something productive.

TRACEY PETERSON:
We are currently

traveling with about
$7,000 worth of camera
gear, computers, and iPads.

So not only are we really
worried about our gear being

taken from us or being damaged
as we have to check it in now,

but also the memories we've
made for the past month, that

can just be swiped
within a second
and with no thought at all.
